>From: Colin Green <cgreen@...>
>
>It just so happens I have a spare Linux box under my desk - what are the
>chances of that? :)  It's only a pentiumII 266 though.

Thanks!  Every little bit helps.  Heck, last night I took my old laptop with 
a dead hard drive and booted it with a knoppix CD and turned it into a 
client!

There is now a new client script, though.  The new script supports 
compression of the data, so I can save a bunch on my internet bandwidth.  
All those downloads were slowing my internet connection to a crawl.

The new script is a shell script (rather than perl), and in addition to 
compression, it includes an auto-update feature.  If I change the script on 
the server, all clients will be running the new version as soon as they 
finish the sample they are working on.  It also supports running multiple 
copies in the same directory, for multi-processor boxes or machines with an 
abundance of horsepower.

The url for the new client script is

http://www.hanlonsrazor.com:81/neat/iex/iex_client.sh

The first time you run it, it creates a config.sh file.  Customized settings 
are stored there so that when the script is updated, the customizations are 
not lost.  Once you have customized the config file, run the script again 
and it will start working.

Please, please update to the latest client so I can get my internet speed 
back! :)

>Anyway I got it running your experiment with no problems.

Good.

>Should I just leave it running for a while?

As long as you can spare...once you update the script. :)

>It's not going to cause a problem if you decide to restart the experiment 
>is it?

Nope, not at all.  It doesn't care what state the experiment is in, it just 
downloads source files, compiles them, executes them, and then sends the 
results back.  It could care less if we are on generation 1 or generation 1 
million.

In fact, I could make a minor modification to it that lets you configure the 
URL for fetching work packets and for where you return the results, and the 
client would then be a totally generic distributed NEAT client.
